column2: We had Avocado Toast and lemon ricotta toast. It is self-service. When we arrived at 9 AM, there was a long queue. The wait was fortunately not long. My toast was ok, a bit too hard for me and definitely not worth the price. The tables were not clean. Cheap knife that hardly cut through the hard crust of my toast. My latte was good.

Took a pizza cooking class here today. It was a lot of fun. Great environment and people, and we learned a few things about cooking pizza along the way. Had some expresso and enjoyed the coffee shop before the class. The bread here is amazing. They mill their own fluor and bake their own bread daily. Will definitely be back.

Wonderful service, delicious, freshly brewed coffee and garlic toast with an egg 🍳 simply placed in the middle, yum!! Add to that pleasant conversations with strangers who love their pets, your family, or friends and well you found yourself a perfect little breakfast joint. #enjoy and when you bite into that toast or drink that oh so yummy coffee don’t forget to stop and thank me 🤭☺️

I really enjoyed my visit. The place smells like freshly made bread with many selections such as sourdough and rye bread. The service is also fairly fast depending on the time. When I went it was very busy due to a public holiday.

great brunch spot with light meals and known for their toast. the lines, although long on weekends, go by pretty quickly but seating is hard to come by. would go again but not the top of my list.  they use neighbor bakehouse pastries and four barrel coffee!  smoked trout toast: layers of flavor in each ingredient, toast is a little too hard though. would recommend!

This is a really nice place to meet up with friends for breakfast or brunch. It has a nice vibe. They do various different “Toasts.” Which is fun.  Everything has a really healthy taste and vibe. You can also buy fresh bread.  I tried the Smoked Trout Toast. Their in-house crème fraîche is really yummy, and the toast presentation was good. The dish was good - I just felt like it could have been better.  I also had a hot chocolate, however, it tasted more like a hot cocoa.
Great artisnal bakery with a delicious selection of toast & toppings for brunch. The loafs of bread are divine and feature a special bread of the week.

I was here last in the Before Times. I felt like changing things up and checking it out again.  It's as fantastic as I remember it. I had the avocado mash toast and it was absolutely delicious. I love the atmosphere. There's a parklet outside and they have for here mugs and dishes.  I made it a point to go early because I know it gets really busy and it was already filling up
A bit crowded for a Sunday morning! The line went out of the door. But their coffee was really good. I also liked the avocado toast.

You cant go wrong with this place!Definitely recommend Avocado Mash served over a nice thick slice of toast drizzled with what looked like EVOO and a light sprinkle of salt. It was delicious. We gambled with willing to missing our flight in order to stop by here and have another the next day (we made it SFO on time). Their Cinnamon sugar toast was good too. I usually like my coffee with milk and sugar but glad I didn't add anything to my Latte. It was rich and smooth! This is a MUST VISIT place and its right around the corner from The Painted Ladies.

Amazing bread, toasts are all to die for, awesome espresso drinks. Can be a bit of a wait and battle for a seat but makes for an overall enjoyable and social experience. I got a cortado with oat and it was perfection!
I love coming to the mill. It is spacious and stylish and a great spot to watch people. The coffee is phenomenal. The bread is even better although quite pricey. ♥️this spot.

Great spot for gourmet toast and coffee on Divisadero. Eat in with the cool kids at the communal table, grab a little bistro table, or enjoy outside (Painted Ladies in Alamo Square are just a couple blocks away). You can also pick up a loaf of bread for take away.

Great vibe, really great breads from Josey the bread baker and lots of pastries from Neighbor Bakehouse.  The staff taking orders are always friendly.  We did bring our own coffee mugs, and the person taking our order was super nice about it and even gave an generous pour.  I’m recently gluten free and was pleasantly surprised to find out all the toast combos can be made on GF bread. I was a bit disappointed once I picked up my order to see that the GF bread options was quite a bit smaller than the standard bread options for all toasts. Wakes up to the pick up counter area and saw the contrast between my slice and several others.  It’s great to have a GF option and I appreciate it being available. That slice was super fresh but very dense, lots of nuts and seeds and while it was soft felt more like a seed thick cracker, than a slice of traditional the mill, soft, fluffy bread.  I’ll definitely be back and want to try the ricotta toast but will probably try a different GF options next time.

This is a great spot to grab a coffee / snack and meet up with a friend. They have fresh bread and other baked goods for purchase as well as pantry items like olive oil and wines from local sellers. I highly recommend The Mill!

We visited The Mill for brunch and had a positive experience. It wasn’t too busy, so we were able to find a table by the window after we placed our order. We ordered a coffee and latte with an avocado mash toast and a cinnamon sugar toast. Both of the toasts were delicious. The bread was thick and tasted great. The staff was friendly and the inside of the store was clean. I would love to visit again and try some of the other items.

A baker recommended this place to me - not for the ambiance, or coffee, or pastries (all of which are stellar). But for the quality of the bread which is absolutely top tier.  You can buy slices at the Mill, but the best way to experience it by far is to buy a loaf to take home (recommend the standard Country loaf or Seed Feast). You can garnish it with quality butter, jam, avocados, lox, almond butter, etc. You’ll get a ton of bang for your buck and the quality is unbelievable. Josey Baker is a legend among bread bakers and it makes sense why.
I love the simplicity of this brunch spot! It’s literally just different toast flavours and combination. I got eggs on garlic toast and it was delicious.

The Mill is a very cute local coffee shop. I really liked the atmosphere on envibe app and decided to check it out! It is quite small cafe near Alamo Square park, but it feels like all the locals go there. Would recommend to check it out on weekend morning!:)
Best whole wheat sourdough you’ll ever have! Also took their pizza making class which I highly recommend. Can get a bit busy in the weekends which isn’t surprising for a great spot like this.

My daughter took me to The Mill a few days ago. We went back today. They carry Josey Baker Bread as well as an array of delicious pastries. I'm hooked on the Plum Pistachio Crumb Cake.  They make a nice oat milk cappuccino too. The ambience of the restaurant is warm and welcoming.

This breakfast place has great coffee and pastries. I loved the pistachio croissant, totally worth a try! They would run out of the bakery items though so early morning is a good time to go. They don't have a lot of seating compared to the crowd so plan accordingly. The toasts are good too but I like the bakery better
Fantastic latte and the cinnamon sugar toast is so simple but truly delicious. Love the decor and atmosphere

This was the best bread I've ever had. Had the avocado toast and the cinnamon sugar toast along with an americano, all so good. The vibe is cool, really great art hung up on the walls, and the prices are good.

I was recommended this cafe because of their bread and it lived up to expectations! We loved the avocado toast. The bread looks huge but it's actually the perfect size because you can taste the bread itself. We also picked up an everything croissant and a seasonal pistachio and blackberry croissant and both were buttery and delicious.

We visited the Mill on a Tuesday and really liked the coffee, service and the ambience! It’s really spacious and seems ideal for coffeeshop working. They also had lots of great looking bread loaves and toasts we want to come back to try.

I absolutely love The Mill. Yes, the lines are long. Yes, it is worth it. Both the coffee and the toasts are totally delicious. The wonderful tartness of the sourdough-based breads is a unique delight. The coffee and espresso are smooth yet complex. Round and bold cold brew. And the staff are professional and efficient but somehow retain a degree of warmth and welcoming hospitality. Also, they are adorable. Get the raised vanilla donut and, heck, the vegan chocolate while you're at it--take those to-go, because you'll want to order the cinnamon toast, avocado toast, and egg in a hole. I love this place so much that I usually book a hotel or airbnb within walking distance when I visit the Bay. I'm obsessed.
A place where a single piece of toast is delicious!

I ordered the Avocado Toast and Smoked Trout. The avocado toast was yummy, a little oily. The bread was good. The smoked trout was really good.. I wish it was served on a larger piece of toast it was small. I had to wait about 15 mins to receive my order. Overall, both were good and moderately well priced. I'd recommend stopping here for breakfast or lunch.

I ordered the Americano... Espresso Coffee is OK... Good not great.  But they serve almond milk as an alternative to regular milk.  Breads look good but somewhat overpriced.  I was listening to a customer ask an associate about the taste of rye. That customer had too much time on her hands. And let's just say, the associate was not very knowledgeable. This place is cool with local works of art.  Attracts a very hipster crowd that likes to sit, enjoy coffee and with their good companions.

Love the toast here. It’s famous for its bread, which means the toast is delicious but comes at a premium $$$ hot chocolate & latte are both incredible too. Go early to beat the rush lines can be around the block in peak hours.
Gorgeous space with amazing toast. I got the almond butter toast and it was incredible. Communal tables inside and outside. Coffee was really good too.

Bar none the best bread in the city, maybe the best bread in the world. It’s just so damn good, if you haven’t tried it before, what are you waiting for?  My favorite has to be the Wonder Bread, I think it’s got to be the square shape. When the Wonder Bread’s sold out, the Country is usually my second choice.  Any of the breads that you get in store are also great.

Best coffee and breakfast at a coffee shop.  Their hand baked artisan on-site bakery is incredible.  We loved their trout toast and egg in a hole.  Their croissants and pain au chocolates are perfectly flaky and flavorful.  The line moves quickly and they are customer centric.

Truly the best piece of bread I’ve ever had. I ordered the ricotta toast and it was perfection. The crumb texture and taste of the bread was honestly life changing. I wish I lived closer so I could buy it more often.
Love coming here to grab a loaf of bread for the week. Their baked goods are pretty tasty also.  The line may look long but it goes by quickly by their fast service.
Fav breakfast in SF. We were lucky to find a spot in the shared table. Coffee and treats were great, the staff very friendly. Ned a Mill close to me 🤍highly recommended

Great place for toast lovers. The bread is fantastic and the options for toast are far reaching. The place is open and a bit loud however you can easily have a conversation with the person across from you. There are small tables lining the walls with ponger tables in the middle. Also a small outdoor bench section in front. The coffee is good (four barrel). I certainly enjoyed the mocha. There were few power outlets so I do not think this would be an easy place to work on a computer. Overall, great spot for some food and coffee.
This place is dog-friendly. A nice place to post up with a laptop for an hour and seek funding for your startup.

Wow! We stopped in and grabbed some toasts and Parmesan black pepper bun and blackberry pistachio croissant. The bun and croissant were insanely delicious. The bread used for the toast was super yummy.

Pretty interesting place for breakfast! Their coffees are awesome! The toast style breakfast are very delicious! Portions are pretty small! You can get two different toasts to try a variety! Their breads are awesome as well! Price can be high imo. Don’t get the cinnamon toast! It is a fat toast with tons of brown sugar and cinnamon! Not a great choice! Also, the place is packed so good luck finding a place to sit lol!

Omg how did I not discover this place sooner??? Especially since my nail salon is 3 blocks away. First of all can it get better than Four Barrel Coffee AND a bakery in one? I ordered the most delicious cappuccino and they don’t use Clover brand milk! I also had the most incredible Earl Grey Olive Oil cake. My favorite thing I ordered 2 days in a row was the Almond Butter Toast on their wheat toast that it came with. Thanks to the most incredible gal that rung me up, Michelle, she told me how incredible the toast is and how fresh and warm and toasty on the outside that I couldn’t resist. She also suggested drizzling honey and she was on point. She was a gem and brightened my day. The place is usually packed especially on weekends. They are constantly making fresh bread and you can see it over the counter. They also play their music from a record player! Love love this place!

I’ve been to The Mill dozens of times for coffee, toast or pastries. I think it is one of the best coffee shops in San Francisco. The ambiance combined with the tastiness of the treats makes every visit pleasurable. I especially love the cinnamon sugar toast. This is a great place to work from for several hours or to meet a friend. I could not recommend the Mill enough. My only complaint is that it can get crowders during the day, making it difficult to find a place to sit.

Great ambience and their bread and pastries looked amazing! Willing to come back to try these. I only stopped by for some coffee, but it was the worst one i’ve ever had before because of how bitter it was. If you like bitter coffee then this place is for you, otherwise would just go elsewhere. Their latte art is nice though.
When I checked menu, I can't believe they charged $4- $8 for a toast. But it was really great and special, coffee was good as well. Love the decorations here.

The Mill is my favorite coffee shop in SF. The atmosphere is always so inviting and cozy. The coffee is always fresh and delicious, they also have a great selection of pastries and breads. The only downside is the seating is limited, so I have to order to-go or stand around until a seat becomes available. Overall I highly recommend checking it out.

I went following a Google Maps suggestion and while for the most part it was "ok", I expected more from a cafe with such a long line!, which means you need to wait a while to order, even if it is for takeout. The place is beautiful, nice industrial retro style. The amount of options is more limited than I expected, very specific menu and prices are far from cheap. I ordered a muffin and it was truly delicious, but it was so small that I felt like missing some bites, specially for the price. I also got a croissant which was good, mostly because you could tell it was quite fresh, yet it was not memorable. And I got a a hot chocolate and that was disappointing, average would almost be a an understatement, they need to up their game in that field. The 4 stars are for the muffin, the -1 for the chocolate.
Just lost my mind after having egg in a hole with sage garlic butter with a side of avocado . Ooohhhh myyyy goooood🤩🤩 …
The best toast you will ever have. Beautiful breads, tasty locally sourced toppings and wonderful coffee. A beautiful space it's a great place to sit and enjoy the best toast you've ever had.

My friend told me I couldn't go to San Fran without going the The Mill and having one of their toasts... So I did just that, and I regret nothing!! I'm not the type of person to usually order a toast when I eat out, but this one was so gooooood. Their bread is so fresh and good. The mix of almond butter + butter + sea salt is amazingly savoury, yet so simple to recreate at home!

Bread is exceptional, but I always just grab and go. Have never stayed to eat because the noise level inside is absolutely insane, to the point where it's probably an occupational hazard for the employees.
Really tasty toasts and cappuccino! Worth the money! It’s really pleasant to find a place in the city with such a quality of bread and ingredients.
great place, good coffee and the avocado toast is amazing. I enjoy having breakfast here, and it’s also a good spot to work. staff are great.

Poor choice of food and milk for the coffee. Small and quite pricey portions. Staff could be more friendly and I had an impression that I’m an intruder there. There is a lot of space for work and study but forget about Wi-Fi... There are way nicer places in the neighborhood.
Fantastic place to enjoy breakfast and immerse in SF lifestyle. Great interior, great food, great vibe, and most important great staff 💯😍 …

I thought the coffee was decent, they ran out of vanilla flavoring by the time I got there but I would say it was decent. We also grabbed a mushroom and cheese filling pastry and it’s not as tempting cold, they’re not allowed to warm things up for you but it’s conveniently located next to the painted ladies block.
One of my go-to cafés. The coffee and pastries are amazing, and all the bread/toast are to die for! The ambiance and indoor decor are super great. Amazing vibe!
Beautiful coffee shop in a convenient location. Double shot of espresso was delicious and my wife loved her tea. Will definitely visit again!
Best espresso I have ever had here in SF the bread 🍞 is so good you wont go wrong with smashed avocado and almond toast.

My favorite local coffee shop. It has great design/vibe, everyone who works there is friendly, and their toasts are delicious. Not to mention good espresso, as well as delicious bread made in-house, that's also for sale by the loaf. At night they switch to pizza and booze, so it's great for all times of day. Always super full so it's hard to find seating, but the outdoor public parklet helps. Cannot recommend enough.
Favourite coffee shop in the city. Incredible poppyseed walnut babka and avocado toast. 😍
Great place to have coffee while in the area! Garlic Knot was amazing. The coffee also tasted good. The atmosphere is extremely good. The music was nice!
Great place to grab a quick bite and coffee

Sounds odd for something as simple as toast to be brilliantly addicting but it just is!  With a wide variety of freshly made roasts, coffees, and a lot of sitting area in a friendly and cool environment, The Mill meets all your hipster & family needs.  A classic tradition when I visit, Mahalos 🤙 Only downside is the crowds and the prices
Loved everything: the food, avo toast and the pastries, and the coffee. Nice to sit and observe/chat with the people around you.
very good pastries (best ones I've had in the bay). beautiful space. gets noisy. their coffe is not as good.
Best toasts in SF! I had the avocado one and the pesto pine nuts and both were amazing! Also, the coffee at this place is really good! Nice location and setup, feels spacious and welcoming!

Great spot for a cup of coffee and a delicious piece of homemade toast baked in house. Yes it's pricey, but what place isn't here in the city? This place gets super crowded around 10, so get here earlier to avoid a longer line. Nice friendly staff.

We got the lemon ricotta + jam on the dark rye. The toast was good overall but one thing I wanted to note was that the guy who was making the toast was not wearing any gloves and kept touching his mask, clothes, other stuffs on his kitchen table then back on making the toast with bare hands without not washing his hands. Tbh I was a bit shocked watching that so couldn’t finish our toast. It just feels very unhygienic during this covid period…
Omg! Here provides good coffee! I would like latte with oat milk! ! ! Nice environment and pleasure bakery smell~~~ the price is reasonable! Super recommend here!

This place always has a long line, even in the COVID-19 pandemic! I didn’t understand, but I finally tried the bread for myself, and now I get it. The country loaf that I bought was so fresh and one of the most delicious breads I’ve ever had. The coffee and toast is also good but really the main attraction is the BREAD 😋🍞 …

Love this chill coffee shop and always visit when in town. They offer pastries and toasts, and sell fresh bread and a few other items. Communal seating and a few benches get very busy, but usually if you wait, one will open up.

Hands down my favorite coffee shop in the city. Incredible hand made fresh toast with various toppings. Coffee is made to order and always beautifully presented. I love the bright atmosphere with the public seating outside.
Great Cafe, delicious bread, delicious toast. I never thought I would consider 9 bucks for avocado toast worth it but it totally is.
This toast is worth every dime! So good! The cinnamon sugar is the perfect mix of buttery, sweet, and salty. Excellent with their coffee
Usual good coffee and baked goods combination in a usual SF hipster set up. In a good way though. You will not be disappointed.
Great place to visit and have a cup of coffee. The avocado toast is a must. Their coffee is from Four Barrel roasters.
Josey Baker knows how to bake bread! I ordered the smoked trout on whole grain bread -- and it was freaking delicious! Very cool spot and friendly service.
Nice space and delicious bread! Got the hazelnut chocolate toast—  it’s a bit on the pricey side but it’s SF. I’ll definitely be back to buy a loaf, they have a great selection of bread.

Excellent neighborhood coffee shop with fresh bread. Communal tables and personal ones. The adventure bread is delicious. They have some ceramics for sale. Go for pizza night too. They have an awesome parklet and bike parking too.

A baker recommended this  - not for the ambiance, or coffee, or pastries (all of which are stellar). But for the quality of the bread which is absolutely top tier.  You can buy slices at the Mill, but the best way to experience it by far is to buy a loaf to take home (recommend the standard Country loaf or Seed Feast). You can garnish it with quality butter, jam, avocados, lox, almond butter, etc. You’ll get a ton of bang for your buck and the quality is unbelievable. Josey Baker is a legend among bread bakers.
omg this just made my day, thank you Sarah Jacobs, YOU are a legend too :) love, Josey
Been going here for over a decade and the service and quality are consistently good! Grab your coffee and food to-go and take a walk around Alamo Square Park a short block away.

Best bread in the city if you are looking for clean and honest bread. Jose is one of the few places making 100% rye bread. Pair that with four barrel coffee and you got the perfect spot. But people know so it is quite busy :)
The homemade breads, foods, coffees, and ambience are incredible. I can't believe anyone would give this place less than 5 stars. One block from painted ladies.
Bought a loaf of bread and croissant - bread top notch, has to be top five in city. Croissant was okay maybe try the other pastries instead.

The Mill is a beautiful light-filled coffee shop with amazing coffee and toast. It’s a beautiful vibe. Coffees are a bit pricy at $6+ for an Almond Latte, but I still go out of my way to visit on every trip! It’s an experience. I do miss their Atelier Dion ceramic mugs - but nonetheless, it’s a great spot! A must try!

Good service, nice little Cafe with good ambience. There is some outdoor seating as well. Overall I loved the experience and would definitely comeback again. Could get crowded sometimes so be ready for little wait, and I would recommend to try cinnamon sugar toast with seat salt it was the best I had like 3 when I tried it for the first time.

The almond milk Cappuccino cost $5.50..and it was just okay. I found the coffee not to only be over priced but also not any too great. Donuts we're good, but $15+ for 2 donuts and coffee it's a bit steep. I'd rather go to Pinhole in Bernal heights.

The toasts are amazing, my favorite is the Hummus Toast. They make their own bread fresh, and it shows in the toast. The coffee is good as well, and it is a pleasant setting. They don’t have WiFi or power outlets, so if you’re planning to work there, go prepared. Also, it can be slightly windy even inside the cafe, so carry a jacket, even in summer.

Extremely delicious pastries, especially pistachio and everything croissants. Coffee is above 5 stars. The bread is so good! Adrian is the mood setter for the place. This breakfast and service made my day!

They are very generous with their ingredients -- chunky pieces of bread with heaping mounds of avocado, almond butter, trout, or whatever choice of toast you make. The brown rye with seasonal jam is the most petite but the flavor is still RICH. They also have a wide selection of pastries that are unlike any other in the city, such as the earl grey olive oil cake or the Mexican cookies. Just wow.
Pine nuts tart. THIS IS MAGIC!!! Absolute must!
They have hemp mylk as a milk alternative. Great coffee and space.
The pistachio+blackberry croissant is so amazing, they run out quick so you need to get there before 10 am to find it. The levain bread loaf is also the best bread I have eaten in the area.
Loved the coffee and spacious chill vibe. No Wi-Fi, adding to the character of the cafe.
My favorite fancy toast ( that tastes amazing) and coffee shop. I've known the mill since it was a little snack in 2012 - it's always a delight with seasonal surprises

I’ve been coming here since it opened. It’s special and high quality. But I do think the pizza slices take way too long to be ready! Just seems like lots of pizza is sitting back there ready to be served and the servers are taking their sweet time. Especially slices to go.
Probably the best bread in the city! And the coffee is great too.

A great cafe to get some work done! I love the aesthetic of the cafe, but the toast is overpriced IMO and the lack of outlets and seats is why I would give it three stars overall.  I love the bread and coffee and would come back if I wanted to find a place to read a book or do a little work, but definitely going to come earlier to make sure I can get a seat.
Really lame that they don’t do drip coffee refills, drip coffee is almost $5… Sightglass always refills unlimited

The good: excellent baked goods (parmesan peppercorn bun is my favorite) and coffee. Lovely, airy space with great design and plenty of natural light, records often playing. Customers are fancy city folks, excellent people watching.  The bad: it's expensive and pretentious. I get that they have Divisadero rent to pay. I was willing to overlook it for several years. But after the 3rd out-of-town houseguest I suggested The Mill to returned with comments about the pretentiousness they experienced, generally in regard to the service, I figured it's time to admit it. Perhaps it has gotten better; the last guest described the service this way a few months ago and I know good help is hard to find in a tight labor market. The consistency of the feedback was undeniable though.  There are other bakeries and cafes nearby.

Toast is toast. But at The Mill they have a direct line to Jesus’ personal collection of loaves. You can’t fathom how good their coffee, food and atmosphere are. Is it possible to give coffee shops Michelin stars? Shout out to Anna for giving an amazing dealers choice.
Cute coffee place. Best for groups. It’s an amazing bakery. Loved the loaf.
A can't-miss SF food experience! Don't leave the city without getting the cinnamon sugar toast. Absolutely incredible freshly-baked bread with an authentic SF atmosphere.
Yes. This is a 5 star place. Vibe, service, drinks, and food are all worth it.
Very laid back, spacious and good lighting. The coffee and croissants are wonderful. The toasts were decent. I'm more likely to come back for the ambience and the coffee.

My wife and I stopped in for a quick piece of toast and coffee before heading off to Dolores Park. Gotta say, we felt very much in the company of locals and the food was awesome and quick. Must stop if your in the area and need a quick delicious bite while feeling like a local.

I never order a salad anywhere basically but I decided to try it here. I got the “Big Salad” and it was super filling. My friend got the beets veggie pizza which also looked delicious. I think I’ll be back here again soon. Apparently their pizza changes every single week.

The best toast and such amazing coffee! I lived in SF for a few months and dream about this place between visits. It is a little expensive for toast, but not expensive when you consider that it is the best toast in the world.

Spacious coffee shop serving Four Barrel coffee. The place is fronted by large windows and gets a lot of light. The latte I had here was very nicely made. Seating indoor is available at a few individual tables as well as a large communal table. Lines can be long.

The croissant that I got was amazing, delicious and I’d order another one in a split second. The chocolate chip cookie was okay, very small for the price and tasted too dry, it crumbled when I took a bite.  The real nose dive was the coffee, I ordered a mocha and the espresso tasted burnt. I could taste a deep burn flavor and it made it undrinkable. I had to throw it away. I would have asked for a remake but I had already left and was too far away to go back. Maybe it was the oat milk that they over steamed, if that’s possible, but it bad. And for a $6.50 I’d expect much better quality. Every few coffees the baristas should taste the coffee to make sure it’s good.  I’d only return for the pastries but definitely not the coffee.
The cappuccino is unbelievably good and the bread is a dream for a European. The best breakfast spot! And also great pottery, which you can buy there.

Really cute coffee shop. They make their own bread and other baked goods. You can get a slice of toast with different spreads such as pumpkin. This place is very pricey for what your getting and they don’t provide WiFi.
The vibe, coffee, music was great. But I can't give past 2 stars when I find pubic hair half way through my cinnamon knot dessert :(
What an amazing coffee shop. Smoked trout toasts were amazing. But even better - pistachio blueberry croissant - priceless! Thank you so much for such a great experience!

I went in the morning. It was super busy. That is not a bad thing. I did not wait too long. I bought the country bread, a mocha, and there version of a coffee cake.  The country bread was delicious. It is like a wheat sourdough bread that is bumped up a notch. I would buy it again. It’s great with a garlic spread.  Their version of a coffee cake was excellent. It was light, moist, and just the right sweetness to it. I recommend it.  The mocha on the other hand, was a disappointment. It tasted more like a latte than mocha. It was bitter with no taste of chocolate to it. I recommend that they put more chocolate in it to counter the bitterness.  The service was good. They were helpful. Overall, a good place to go.
Monday Pizza is pretty good, recommended if the wait is not too bad
I just ate a loaf of bread for breakfast, and I have no regrets. Truly outstanding bread. I got some kind of loaf with black pepper and parmesan in it, and it might be my favorite thing ever.

Poster child of a true coffee shop. Simple menu, fresh ingredients, open space...clatter of dishes echo through the backgrounds of chatter & ease. I sat & watched a barista engaged in his craft with such attention. Another prepping loafs of delicious goodness set on the shelving. I fell in love. The ambience, the free spirit of every individual behind the counter. The epitome of coolness.
If you visit this area stop here for a coffee! Real espresso’s in light stylish bistrot/ bar setting.

Old fashioned coffee shop with no WiFi, no reservations, and no non-service dogs allowed. Just the most inventive treats to go along with their standard coffees menu. We went for the Trout on Toast and the Egg in the Hole.
Delicious bread with toppings options served up with their delicious coffee. It is a busy place but for a reason.
Coffee is excellent, but it's worth coming just for the fresh baked bread smell.
A really chill place. Love the design and the sunshine through the roof and windows!
Pretentious. There's not enough seating, no outlets, and no Wifi. Very clear they don't want you to hang out for very long. It was  $10 for 1 egg in a slice of bread. Kind of silly, won't come back.
Love their lattes and toast.
Nice quiet space with lots of room and fresh air! Good house coffee… nice porch!
Always looking out for vibes in a coffee place. And what a lovely place this was. Sat by large windows to enjoy a latte.

Great space, no WiFi, friendly staff, coffee was a bit disappointing. (4/5 green stars) Hmmmm. Everyone in here looks like a model – I’m wondering what’s going on. Perhaps I’m just not used to spending Saturday afternoon in a swanky SF hood.  Or maybe it’s the prices – a slice of toast with cream cheese was $3.75 in 2014 and today it’s $7 (although it now contains pesto and pine nuts). I’ve no specific problem with them charging as much as they like if they use good ingredients – just be aware of the price before you drool too much over the toast photos. The main attractions are the space, and that it’s a collaboration between Josey Baker Bread and Four Barrel Coffee.  You know about the toast already, so I won’t go into it ;-)  I had a straight up coffee ($3.50) and thought it was a bit lackluster to be honest. Disappointingly, they don’t do pour-overs and my coffee tasted like it had been there a while. Also weird that it seemed a little over-roasted and bitter, considering that they don’t do dark roasts. It’s still a little better than average coffee – it’s just that I have high expectations because of the reputation. They just got new coffee mugs – beautiful stoneware made locally by Sven Ceramics. The space is very pretty - nicely laid out with individual tables, a long communal table, and lots of floor space. Good music playing too. No WiFi but it’s still a place where you can hang out with a book or laptop and not feel like an oddball.  I’m also giving them 4/5 “green stars” for social and environmental impact based on these reasons:  Positives: • Four Barrel recently switched to compostable coffee bags. • Bread is made from organic grain, often local. • On their blog they mention covering health insurance for staff. • Mostly vegetarian menu. • Their milk is from St. Benoit, an organic farm in Sonoma that (re)uses glass bottles. • Coffee is sourced by direct trade partnerships, documented on the Four Barrel site. • They use real glasses for water rather than plastic. • Nice locally made ceramics.  Room for Improvement:  • Four Barrel doesn’t publish prices paid for green coffee. On their site they say “it would be an impossible waste of time for us to use one phrase to describe how and why we buy the coffees that we do.” This is understandable on one hand but also a bit of a cop out. They should at least try to be more transparent.  • Similarly, they generally don’t discuss environmental conditions of the farms they source from. It’s nice to see photos of the farmers but it would be good to see more photos of the farms themselves, with more discussion on things like percentage shade cover and sustainability.  • A lot of their toast is sold to go, in a tray with a plastic lid. It’s probably compostable (I didn’t get a chance to check) but it does seem a bit of a shame to sell something like toast and package it in a plastic box – they could have gone with cardboard but I think they want to show off how pretty the toast looks. So I’m a bit disappointed there that they are choosing form (marketing) over environmental impact. Of course, you can always have your toast for there and forgo the box. Interested in writing green star reviews? If so, contact me! (greenstarsproject)

The atmosphere here is chill. Gives you that, step back and relax feeling. Relax outside or inside with the natural sunlight, coming through the glass windowed wall. The tunes were uppity/chill, if that makes sense. Took a bit to get a piece of toast with jam. Tasted like toast with jam. Great bread.  Come here for the atmosphere and coffee. Chillax, listen to the tunes and smile.
The rye toast seemed a little thin for $8. But always love the cappuccinos here.

Drip coffee was quite good! The person at the register said they have a "fancy high tech drip machine" that's as good or better than pour over in his opinion. Cortado was brewed a little weakly. Based on how it tasted I'm guessing the grind size was too large, but it was alright. Got lemon ricotta toast on rye (awesome, I don't know what the jam was but it was fantastic) and the salted almond butter on country bread (bread was awesome, almond butter was standard and nothing particularly special). Prices are your usual SF prices for fancy toast and fancy coffee. Shop was very cute, had lots of nice indoor space to sit, and there was lovely outdoor seating. There's a lot of room to park yourself, for a small coffee shop. The person at the register was super friendly and kind.  We ordered avocado toast at first and he came outside to tell us that they were out, offer us a replacement, and comp our order! Super nice!

Favorite coffee shop & bakery in the area. This is the shop that taught me to bake bread! There’s really two shops combined here: four barrel coffee and Josey the baker bread. The staff is kind and the coffee & food is best in the city IMO. Seating is usually available too. Because of its greatness, the mill is very busy on weekend mornings, with a line out the door common. It’s also not cheap by any means, though I think it’s a unique spot that’s worth it.

There're a lot of debates going on if a toast (I mean a piece of bread) could cost $5+, BUT! I would totally recommend to experience this place on your own.  I like to sit there sipping on my cup of coffee and observe the team work and craziness going on in a bakery corner.  If you get lucky, you'll meet the owner – Josey Baker – doing his job. Oh, don't worry, you'll know it's him!
Very cool place with awesome vibes. No wifi tho, so only 3 stars for me... Edit - they play really cool indie music from vinyl discs, so only for that they deserve an additional star :)

Got a cappuccino. It was pricey (over $5) and a  salted chocolate babka. Cappuccino was just okay (wasn't smooth, a little too strong and bitter for me), but the babka was good. Just another pricey hipster coffee spot.

I’ve been looking for a place for reaaallly good drip coffee and this place so far is the winner. The bread is also worth the trip, I like to get the toast with the seasonal jam. The line is sometimes long but it moves fast!
Heavenly toast, four barrel coffee, fresh baked bread, dynamo donuts, neighbor pastries, hipster vibes. An ultimate neighborhood cafe
Very cosy and nice place. Coffee and chocolate are great and so are the toasts!
Service was fast and great. My poor friend dropped his coffee due to his knee and they replaced it at no cost. Very nice of them. They had a cute atmosphere too.
Great toast in hip environment. Somewhat pricey.
Sourdough was good. Coffee was really sour / rancid though, beans may have gone bad. Disappointed but will try again next time.
We sat outside with our pups and had a lovely little coffee break.
Adore this little slice of heaven in the heart of San Francisco! The chocolate hazelnut toast is da bomb diggity!!!

I haven’t been or lived in San Francisco for 5+ years and The Mill still comes across my mind or up in conversation every so often.  If I could choose a cafe to put a couple locations across every major city, it would be this.  Having a diverse selection of fresh baked breads and toppings that meet dietary restrictions is such a treat.  Not to mention sweets for those who prefer them.  Walking in, you are immediately hit with a blast of nose sensation that gets you excited for whatever happens to get to enter your mouth.  Not to mention the space is beautiful and fits perfectly the dishes/drinks they serve.  Take me back.

Absolutely splendid coffee and breads!  We prefer their cappuccinos over lattes. And the adventure bread is pretty amazing if you're gluten free. The bread feels expensive because it's small but it's very very filling and lasts a long time if refrigerated.

I ordered a Mocha, and it used dark chocolate which turned to have sour flavor to me. I asked the barista to remake me a latte, getting a very warm and positive feedback, as well as kind explanation. I am very glad that I finally can get in and order something, previously, it was too popular.
This place is my fav, great service and great pizza! Their cheese pizza is always yummy and they have different veggie pizza :)

The service was excellent. The coffee options were very good. The breads and pastries were freshly made and delicious. Nice ambiance and fun vibe. Really enjoyed going there and can recommend heartily.
Overtly over rated. Mediocre toasts and coffee. Cool interior design thought and what they sell would look goon in your Instagram!
A cozy place to grab coffee in the day, pizza and beer at night. The bread and pizza are amazing.
Good service and vibes👍 Their coffee and pastries were good too! …
My friends and I got four different toasts and they were all amazing, especially the cinnamon sugar one! Some of the best coffee in the city as well!

Average SF prices with above average taste. Trendy, hip, and and nice staff. Seating and outlets are limited so come prepared not to stay. As of 11/3/17 there is no wifi. If it weren't for the wifi, The Mill would be 5 stars.
Coffee: good Croissant: excellent Other pastries: good Décor: nice Service: friendly, a little slow Prices: average for the area
Interesting sourdough class where we learned theory, shaped loaves, enjoyed pizza slices and took our loaves home to bake.
Pizza was very good, very clean modern and the staff is extremely friendly love it.... great coffee shop as well
The Mill is proof that spreading various assortments of butters, jams, and other curiosities on freshly-baked, sliced, and toasted bread will never go out of style.

The finest coffee store ever! Your coffee shop was ideal for students who wanted to unwind or read a book. If you want to go on a date, you may also ask the staff to play music that would make you want to dance with your companion. The town's coffee shop comes highly recommended! Thank you very much, gentlemen!
Amazing pizza and atmosphere. $8 for Avo toast used to be a joke, now it’s a deal. The Mill is a great spot.

I don’t get the hype, to be honest. The coffee is fine, sf priced for sure.The pastries and fine too, nothing mind-blowing. Not sure why the bread is so popular, but maybe I just got the wrong loaf. I recommend Jane the Baker on Geary near Filmore instead, although it’s a bit of a walk from Divis.

Modern bakery and coffee place serving pastries and some other small bites. Portions are relatively small, and prices are probably higher than average. There’s no table service. Staff is friendly. It can get busy

The bread that you can buy here is almost a religious experience. It really is that good!! Just the perfect blend of a crunchy exterior and soft and spongy interior with incredible flavor. And I just love that you can have sourdough made from 100% whole grain flour.  A very special place for bread lovers!

There are two great parts to The Mill… the bread (which is very artisanal and nice), and the ambiance. There’s so much natural light and it’s an amazing place to write or catch up with friends. The coffee is pretty good, of course overpriced but it’s SF so what do you expect?? The highlight is definitely the toast! Yeah it’s $$ but it’s also pretty filling and delicious, always. The baristas are always friendly. It’s located on Divis so it can be a little noisy to get work done (also no wifi for better or for worse). Kind of annoying that so many digital nomads take over the space by hotspotting their laptops…
No Wi-Fi which is annoying. I get it... but c'mon. Toast was great, coffee was groovy. ohhhh, but fix your front door. It squawks.

My favorite bread ! And they make the best toasts ! Coffee is four barrel so it's very good. I come here weekly, they are always busy. They have lots of seating room but hard to find a spot at times because they are always busy. Service is fast and friendly.

Yes, they are busy. During COVID the lines have been long. And they're not cheap. But I'm so grateful they are there-- they're keeping me sane with  their carbs & caffeine!! I love all their bread, but my favorites are Adventure Bread (a dark dense and seedy bread I love to eat with soup to make a full meal) and Red White + Rye (a chewy, well rounded red wheat bread that has some rye in it but no caraway seed, best all-purpose buttered toast I've ever had!!) The toasts they serve at the cafe are also a great mid-day snack, avocado or cinnamon or what have you are all great; you really can't go wrong! I drink their Four Barrel espresso rather than their coffee (though I think that's good too) and it's a perfect gorgeous sweet intense espresso worth biking miles across town for :)  I love them so!!!

I've been trying to come here for years but every time I come to California, I miss the chance to stop in. Finally went in today and loved it. Lovely big space with plenty of seating. The sunlight sifting through while you drink your delicious coffee is very dreamy. Lady who took my order was lacking some customer service - kindness doesn't cost anything. A smile is all it takes sometimes to feel welcomed. Otherwise, would recommend.
Excellent pastries, coffee decor and ambiance. The barista was super nice too.
While buying $4-6 toast might seem like the most stereotypically millennial indulgence, the Mill has perfected the art of toast. If you're into sweet, you can't go wrong with the cinnamon toast. 5/5!
Different ambiance for US, but definitely overrated. Too crowded and noisy on Saturdays.
Love their bread so much! They have delicious pastries and toast to eat at the place. Perfect weekend morning food.

Amazing breads made daily. Their style tends to focus mostly on dense breads that are earthy or unique, but they do have light breads with a softer interior. The crusts are always amazing! Some tend to be a bit rough after being toasted, but all are delicious.  They make different styles of toast that changes daily. I've never been disappointed with any that I've tried.  Coffee style and selection is really good, but nothing amazing.

Went here for breakfast on my birthday and got the avocado toast and the twice baked pistachio croissant.  They were both really good. The croissant was one of the best things I have ever eaten. I will be back for sure!
We travel up to Divisadero just to go to The Mill! Four Barrel coffee done correctly here, and the bakery is a superb pairing with it. Bravo, well done!

Cool options for a smaller breakfast. Loved the different types of toast available. We ordered the cinnamon, avocado, and jam toasts which seemed to all be daily specials that they change frequently. Unfortunately, the seating was very limited, and their coffee was bitter in my opinion.
As an Aussie, we love our breakfast/brunch  Mill 🙏🏻 thank you ❤️❤️ best in town …
Yummy coffee a d good variety of toasts.  Good hangout spot to people watch.

Nice atmosphere. Not cramped like many other cafes in the city. The black iced coffee I had was great - clean and sweet flavors, not bitter at all. Good selection of Four Barrel whole beans and friendly, knowledgeable staff. Prices on par with similar cafes like Blue Bottle.
One of the very best coffee shops in San Francisco. Really good coffee, really nice pastries, and great vibes. Highly recommended.
Most delicious latte I have ever had. Four Barrel delivers such quality beans and the baristas here know how to use them. On top of that, service was quick and polite.

The toast is tasty, though burned along the crust. I like the burnt crust taste, but if you don't like burnt food, you may want to think twice about ordering the toast. I personally like the toast a lot. The coffee was ok. I expected better. I slightly liked the coffee more at Trouble Coffee which was near where I stayed. Neither of these cafes had coffee nearly as good as what I make at home in a $20 Mr. Coffee drip machine with a basic grinder and Kirkland/Starbucks beans from Costco. The mill had a long table filled with people hunched over laptops, hard at work. There was no available seating at first. During the long wait for my toast, I did find a seat along the serving bar area. Waiting without a seat was awkward. I was made to feel in the way because wherever I stood, a staff member would need to get around me or get past. I got a few looks from the staff as if I was a stranger who just walked into Cheers. When I did sit down, I overheard what sounded like a big tech deal being made over some website. I visited during mid morning on a weekday, so I imagine that this place is always crowded with limited or no available seating.

Great open environment. Perfect place for your favorite caffeinated beverage and some super thick-cut Texas toast with toppings of your choosing. Very tasty. Also a great spot for indulging in a little pizza for only $3.50 a slice. Go simple with a cheese or pepperoni pizza, or try specialty slice for the day. Tasty baked goods as well are definitely worth trying out. And of course, Josey Baker bread 👍
Nice coffee and good tasting toasts! I definitely recommend the pumpkin butter one!

Great toast! They have interesting combinations. The bread and spreads are made fresh and have top quality ingredients. The coffee bar makes a solid latte. It can get crowded and you could wait 15-20 minutes for your toast on weekends and holidays.

Yes it's homemade style bread but it's effin incredible.  Part of the appeal is that I don't have the time and patience for making my own bread but it's still good.  Coffee is fine.  I'm not a coffee snob.  I'm really rating this place a 5 because it's close to home, space is great and open, wait is not crazy yet and there is always good people watching.  I'm pretty binary with ratings as well.  Places that warrant a review are either 5 or 1.  Who has time to figure out a 4 from a 5 or any other combination!

This place combines the best of both worlds--awesome coffee roasted in house and authentic SF style bakery. It serves pizza from 6pm.  Seating is plentiful and not cramped. Baristas are friendly and knowledgeable. Outdoor seating is available for dogs and their owners. Very stylish but unpretentious decor. The only criticism I have is that there are no electrical outlets for charging laptops and phones.

A little hipster, a little yuppie, a lot delicious. Their toast is amazing and the coffee is a great compliment. Loved the open floor plan and modern architecture!  It's a little pricey and the lines can get long, but otherwise definitely worth a visit!
Service it’s just ok, food good but cold , they don’t warm up the pastry which makes a big difference on th experience

I personally feel this place is way too crowded during the weekend, there’s no way you can find any seating and honestly, the coffee is ok but not fabulous. I may consider to come back during weekday but definitely not weekend,
Life-changing loaves that everyone should treat themselves to, but get there early because they typically sell out by late morning. Solid coffee and nice place to do work or meet up with friends.

Nice open air seating, and the line moves quickly. Four Barrel coffee is on nitro tap here. Toast is, as expected delicious, whether you like sweet or savory spreads. I just can't justify spending $8 on a piece of avocado toast again.

Cute place near where I live. I love their gluten free Adventure Bread, you have to try it! Their tumeric wellness tea is yummy too. I also took their bread making class as a company team offsite, that was a lot of fun. Great space for coffee and hang out, although a bit pricey and pretty crowded on the weekends.

Excellent coffee at a beautiful location. They really went all out in preparing this space. The baking bread adds an incredible aroma and the coffee is exactly what you've come to expect from Four Barrel. Of course, the prices are right where you would expect them too... $4-6 for toast seems a bit extreme. Otherwise, great!  Not quite 5 stars because of overflowing levels of pretentiousness.

I would say service with a smile but with masks you never know. But yes you can tell they're all smiling. The lattes are amazing. If you need anything other than sugar (i.e. stevia, etc) make sure to ask for it. Great service, delicious bread and really good food.
the bread and toast are great to try.  nice cozy place.

Great Coffee, great breakfast, BEAUTIFUL space but most of all STUNNING outside seating area! If the weather is nice you can not sit better than there and have the best bread breakfast with friends or all by your own! Love it!

So far so good. I had a latte and a chocolate croissant ( not the best I've ever had but good).  There is no WiFi so don't plan to work here if you need internet.  The restaurant design and set up look very pretty.  There is a large variety of breads and toasts too. You can also buy cups and other products

What can one say about $5 toast? People love to hate on it, but it tastes delicious.  Josey Baker bread (made here) is simply fantastic and worth trying if you've never had it. That plus the presence of expertly brewed coffee in a bright, airy space makes this place an enjoyable stop on any tour of the city.  Plus the whole place is painfully hip. A perfect encapsulation of the current San Francisco zeitgeist.
Nice cafe but the brown sugar toast was not as tasty as I would have expected. Whatever type of non-white bread they used didn’t mesh well with the brown sugar flavor and it was a bit over toasted.
The mocha was on the sweet side but still tasty.
Great little coffee shop. Good coffee and nice toasts. I’d come here again

Super hipster joint. I ordered an espresso and toast to get a sense of their standard fare. The espresso was AWFUL - I'm a coffee snob, so I was expecting something really great... but was really disappointed by the sour taste. Sour... not bitter. Ugh. I almost sent it back but figured it wasn't worth it. They were out of toast... so no review there. The space is huge and airy and beautiful, but I feel that's all it has going for it.
Got some cold coffee here. Like the interiors!

The Mill is practically Four Barrel coffee fresh bread - or a bakery powered by Four Barrel coffee, as you like. I have only good things to say about this place. Starting with the quality of their bread, sandwiches, and pastries, to the flavorful different kinds of coffee drinks, and not to mention the nice, modern layout of the store.  Stiff prices, yes, but if you live in San Francisco you're probably used to it by now. It's hard to get seating any time of day unless you show up at 7am, but on sunny days there is outdoor seating in the "parklet" available.  Four Barrel and fresh bread - in for the win.

I am on my third visit to SF and I some how always end up coming here! It's got a great aesthetic, quick service, and friendly baristas! I really love how the toast is t too sweet and that the coffee is thoughtfully crafted! Thanks for always being a spot on my visits!!

The only time I think I will ever say a piece of toast was actually worth $4! Rich and dense bread topped with gooey almond butter, it was just divine. And a great pair to my almond milk coffee. Only complaint I had was that it was a bit chilly as they would only close one of the two open doors. San Francisco can be cold, my coffee shop should be warm and toasty!

Trendy place that specializes in fancy toast. Bread is great and they have about 8 different types of toppings on a given day. Can be very busy and seating is limited but is easy enough to order it and go. Is a little price for what is essentially a slice of bread and a few toppings but very tasty.

It's a great environment to relax eat toast and drink coffee. The toast is amazing and their freshly brewed coffee is so good! The workers are so nice and after you go once you'll end up going every week!

Got to go there for the toast. Its pricey but very good. My favorite is the hazelnut spread with butter and sea salt. They usually have a more savory toast option available which is often different each time I go in. Some of those are really good as well but typically go for something more sweet.

I understand why this is a popular coffeeshop, but it really is kind of overrated. The coffees are fine, not mind blowing. But the toasts. Man, they are not good. Too hard, not enough topping, bland toppings, and just not worth the price. Also, really hard to find parking nearby. Anyway, go once to try it out. I've been here twice, and probably won't be back.

Expensive, but you do get higher quality drinks and eats. Lattes come out at the perfect temp, which usually means they take care not to burn their espresso. And, combined with steamed almond milk, you get a nice nutty character to the latte.  The bread is notable. I usually get the almond butter and butter and sea salt bread.  I've never been here when there wasn't a crowd, so expect to wait in line. Parking in the area is also tough...

I was really excited to come out of my way on a weekend morning for some good coffee and toast. Ordered and the toast came out quickly. I make better toast at home, seriously. Not great at all. The coffee took about 15 minutes to be done. It was good coffee, but there seems to be a major backlog of coffee orders.

By far my most favorite café in SF! The ambiance and interior is preserved from Four Barrels so it's very clean and modern. The bakery is phenomenal here with their toast menu. I'd definitely recommend their wheat toast with home made jam. It hits the spot with their drip coffee! A place that lives up to its hype.

The best chewiest brown breads, rich delicious breakfast pastries, good coffee, light airy atmosphere good for studying if it's not too crowded or just socializing. Staff could be friendlier. Haven't been for pizza and beer but look forward to going.

Famous for it's toast, The Mill also offers lots of tasty pasties, as well as excellent coffee / tea. It's a lovely place with small tables as well as one big tables for people to hang out / work. It's usually easy to get a table and service is quick. Toast is yummy although quite pricey.

I go to this place almost everyday. They put all other coffee places in the area to shame which should come as no surprise because it's Four Barrel Coffee. They also bake bread here which is also really good. I usually get an almond milk latte and I can't recommend it enough. I also like the adventure bread because it's made from seeds and psyllium husks and not flour.

Not all restaurants are for all people. And if you're sensible, this one isn't for you. Coffee was terrible and so was my fellow clientele--which when you're packed in sitting shoulder to shoulder makes a big difference. The workers and service was good though 👌 The food is exspensive, as is San Francisco labor, so no gripes there. But it's been awhile since I've felt that much like a fish out of water, really terrible feeling, I'd never go back.

So this is the famous "$4 toast". Turns out it's not quite $4, and by calling thick chunks of baked-on-the-premises German-quality bread, toasted and liberally covered with homemade cream cheese, faux-Nutella or almond butter "toast" you are doing Josey the baker a gross disservice. That said, their menu does consist almost entirely of these single slices of bread, amazing though it is. The coffee is excellent too.

This is my favorite coffee spot in the city. Coffee by Four Barrel, toast by Josey Baker, a snazzy design (which includes local, rotating art), you really can't go wrong. Lattes and cappuccinos are high quality and can be made with almond milk. For toast, you'll generally find something with cream cheese, cinnamon and sugar, some kind of homemade (or locally made) jam, or almond butter atop all different kinds of bread. I really can't recommend just one because I. Love. Them. All. Also, there's a cute, new parklet out front, and Josey's started making pizza (!) on Mondays. If none of these things can make you linger a little longer, take your coffee and toast to go and stroll through Alamo Square.

Great place to hang out and enjoy the atmosphere. A little bit loud but still enjoyable. Food is very tasty. But it's also very overpriced. Do not expect to get any kind of meat. Plan to pay for the experience and not necessarily to have a full belly. Not in any way ideal for the hungry meat eater who loves big plates.

Excellent atmosphere: double height ceiling with cozy natural light, an open-air bakery and segmented barrista stations, craft pottery for sale, and long communal tables. Usually pretty busy. Highly recommend the mocha for fans of unsweetened dark chocolate; it's very full-bodied. Fresh bread smells abound. Usually pretty busy, though it's rare to not be able to find a space opening up somewhere.

This is the best coffee I've had. The lattes are good and they finish the cup with cool artwork. I love that the jelly they use it whatever fruit is in season. I'm from southern CA and I make sure to visit this coffee shop every time I go to SFO.

I went here once at night, and it was quiet and very relaxing to have a seat and sip a cappuccino.  I love the lofty gallery space and wanted to check it out in the day.  The second time I was here with a friend and we finally demystified the Josey Baker toast and Four Barrel coffee together.  The toast is hearty and a thick cut. I liked the jam-like pumpkin butter more than the almond butter with honey, but would try them both again.  I kind of wish they had a tea or alternative drink for my friend who doesn't drink coffee, but other than that it's a great place to have a light meal or snack, depending on what you think (or your tummy thinks) the portion represents.  You can also buy a loaf of bread.
I'm from New Hampshire and this is the Best toast I've ever eaten! I'd come back just for this. I haven't stopped dreaming about it for months...
Still one of my favourite coffee shops in San Francisco. Fabulous bread and coffee. Beautiful design. Eye watering prices.

This place looks beautiful, clean and is pretty relaxed, if a little hipster. Get there early on a weekend to grab a seat and savour the specialist coffee. Staff are usually friendly and if a little cool for school occasionally. The fresh bread is aces!

It was alright! I had a pistachio croissant which I wish they could heat it up for me but they didn't have the option. The coffee was alright I wish they had filled my cup but it was less than half full. Not impressed after my first visit. Will try their toast one day and hopefully they'd give me a reason to update my review.

I want there because they told me that it was the best bakery in San Francisco. I don't think that's probably true but food is tasty. There some cool opções to buy their bread mix to do it at home. Keep in mind that on weekends lines are very long but the move along quickly.

Pricey coffees that don't taste that great (burned beans).  Their breads taste pretty good but they are overpriced as well and the two I picked were extremely oily which does explain the taste.  Oh and on popular times this place has a 10+ minute wait to just get coffee.
Coffee and toast was good but it was so crowded there was no place to sit and enjoy it

Asked for a light roast coffee, the cute barista poured me a dark roast with a straight but dumb expression. I thought if I should ask him for my money back ($1 tip included for some reason too!), but decided against it and found a cute chair in the back and admired their interior design and all the white people occupying the space. I guess it's a nice space. But their coffee, well, it tasted as good as McDonald's brew tbh. McDonald's is better than Burger King, so it gets 2 stars. 3 star is for Wendy's and 4 star for 5 Guys, I was told.

This place has a great vibe!  I got an Americano and a #1 (rye toast with cream cheese, pepper, and salt), and it was a great savory snack. Though the loaf of bread is $6, and my small slice was $3.75, so I almost felt like I should have just bought the loaf!  The place is very packed - I went at 3 pm and the line was out the door!  Definitely don't go in big groups as it'll be hard to find a place for everyone to sit.  But good vibe!

Really nice place that's a short walk away from the Painted Ladies. Come here for a teabreak after visiting the beautiful Victorian houses. The Mill serves really awesome toast and equally amazing coffee. The ambience of the entire cafe is wonderful, as people just sit there to do their work and catch up with their friends. The staff are all very friendly and helpful, and you can be sure that their recommendations would be great for your appetite. We tried the cinnamon and raisin toast, coupling it with an organic milk latte. Gorgeous tea break. After that, we simply crossed the road for some bbq at 4505 BBQ and Grill. Awesome day!

Don’t do it. It’s tempting. It’s hipster. But there’s absolutely nothing to justify the prices. Except for the coffee. That was tasty. For the record, I had a jam toast on adventure bread and a flat white. Total with tip was 17 bucks!

I stopped by after work to meet with my roommate.  While waiting for her, I ordered a cinnamon and sugar toast and hot chocolate.  Yes, the toast is expensive, but I thought it was delicious, especially with the hot chocolate.  As sweet as it sounds, the hot chocolate wasn't so it actually was a nice balance.  I'm not sure if I'd pay $4 for toast again, but if I happen to be in the area and was in the mood for something filling, I'd stop by.
Busy but great coffee and atmosphere. If you want a table the rotate out pretty fast and plenty of outside seating.

I absolutely love this place! Best bread in town along with Tartine. The cinnamon sugar toast is just mouthwatering good! They only have whole-milk which is annoying. For all the Danes out there this is also a place to get ryebread as we know it!

Yea, this place is great. The Mill has become a nearly-weekly staple for me and my girlfriend. From their delicious toast and espresso drinks to the chic ambience and amazing pastries, I don't see myself straying anytime soon.

Delicious over priced toast. They also have a selection of pastries, fresh baked breads, and pancake mixes. Lots of seating. Not good for groups.  They mill their own grain to make flour. Some of the best bread in San Francisco.  In the afternoon/evening they serve pizza.

Their bread is like flavorful heaven. I don't support the overpriced toast craze, but one bite of this bread will make you reconsider. I'm a particular fan of the Parmesan crusted loaf, but you can't go wrong with any choice. Be sure to arrive early!
Great cafe in great neighborhood. Take a book to read here!

Good coffee, good pizza. The service has been straight up rude before. IDK maybe once you grow to the size of four barrel there's a lack of ownership. The prices are hella high for coffee and regularly see the Tesla / Gbus crowd around. Cool, but not my thing.

I'm surprised by my negative experience at this place.  My friend had been here before, was excited to go again and take me with her. The aesthetic of this place is awesome and so beautiful. They do their toast alright. My friend ordered the chocolate hazelnut, sea salt and butter toast. Size wise, it was huge and taste was good but they put way too much butter on. There were some parts of the bread that was soggy with butter. Now we go on to the coffee which was very unappetizing. We decided to split an almond milk Cappy and I'm so glad we did because ours was barely drinkable. Upon first sip, I noticed that the drink was very watery. I pushed back the foam on top and sure enough, it looked more like drip coffee with a splash of milk not an espresso based drink. I take the drink back to the counter and say that I ordered a Cappy and that this didn't look like a cappy (also to note, they made us an 8 oz Cappy which is always a red flag to me because cappys are traditionally 5 oz drinks). The barista was very dismissive of my concern. He told me that "that's just how their almond milk is". This is also a red flag because it's 2019 and very quality barista series milk alternatives is incredibly easy. I asked what brand they used and he said it was called Good Life (so I guess never buy their stuff unless you like watery nut milks?). I ask him what I can do to get a Cappy like the classic 1:3 foam, milk, coffee ratio and he says thats just impossible with their nut milks. He also tells me that when the drinks are sitting out for 10-15 minutes, they get that curdly watery look. I clarified to him that we had gotten this drink way less than 10 minutes ago. The barista then challenged me saying that he could look at the receipt so check the time stamp. I just told him that I didn't think that was necessary (and also, what would be the point of that?). Then he told me that there is no point in trying the other milk alternative option, hemp, because it's going to do the same thing. I decide to risk it ( I guess) and when it came out, it was at least not all curdled like the last one but it was still incredibly watery and barely any microfoam on top. The barista acted like it was weird for me to expect quality alternative milk (like I said, it's 2019 so drinking milk subs isn't weird anymore).  It was such a weird experience and I'm not sure what I could have done to not have this happen. I didn't come up to the barista aggressively. This is a good place to go if you only care about getting some good insta pictures and a loaf of bread to go. Save actually getting coffee so some other San Fransisco favorites.

The wait times and prices are are somewhat ridiculous, but that is the norm in San Francisco coffee shops. Definitely worth going to at least once for the experience, and worth going back to if you have enough free time. Just make sure the cashier actually takes your order; sometimes the people that make the toast never actually get your name.
The coffee was perfect. I love all the breads and menu choices. Check it out.

The atmosphere is lovely here but that's the best part. The pastry I bought was good but pricey and they don't offer to heat it for you. In my experience, friendliness is not a virtue at the Mill. With no outlets and no wifi the general vibe is "give us your money and get out"
Good coffee, overrated toasts, local bread options, long lines.

Expensive however, clean, bright, good coffee, pretty people. I'd give them 5 stars if they had reasonable prices and a bit less attitude.  Difficult to get a seat at times and on the pricy side. For example a large coffee is $3.25 but you is the size of small coffee elsewhere. Most of the seating is at long communal tables but there are a few individual tables and they have a parklet outside that gets afternoon light but shaded and cold in the morning. There are not many of any outlets for chargers so you won't see that many people with laptops surfing or working. Bread is very good but also quite expensive.
Best bread ,, I have been living in America for 6 years.  I finally found the best bread I can eat.  I'm from Turkey, bread is very important to us.

Amazing little place in San Francisco. The toast seems a little pricey until you buy it. The slices are thick and they do not hold back on the toppings you chose (Nutella, jam, pesto, etc.) Certainly could be a meal

Not a bad little coffee shop in SF. I love the aesthetics and atmosphere here but the prices can be a little steep. I love the idea of grabbing a piece of toast with your coffee, but the coast of both items is a little ridiculous. Overall not a bad place to grab a cup of coffee and relax.

I came here after reading reviews myself about Josie Baker Bread.  Yes, the bread is wonderful and I would most definitely buy again.  As for The Mill, I broke down and bought a piece of toast which they are known for.  I paid $3.95 which is pretty pricey.  I also went in the late afternoon and while there weren't many people in front of me, I waited about 10 minutes for my toast.  Really?  The space is wide and open, and would be a great place to set up shop for an afternoon on the laptop, except they don't offer wifi.  There are a lot of other coffee shops in SF that offer more for a better price.  So while it wasn't bad, I just don't get all the hype.

It's a nice space and the toast is good but a lot of the toppings are superfluous e.g. the butter in #4 you can't taste at all. Better off building your own since they charge it a la carte anyway. I only went with a pre combo bc I thought they knew what they were doing.  It's also such a scene. People there to be seen lol.
Took the avocado mash, it was good and the staff was friendly.
Nice a dark mountain rye and hot latte ;-)
hey everyone. Frank here again to report that you’ve never had a thicker, more beautiful, more perfectly prepared slice of toast in your life. come here and eat that toast. the decaf is OK. much love

Great coffee and great toast. The cream cheese on mountain rye bread is a must-have. If you want eat-in, avoid in the early afternoon because the sun beams through the west-facing shopfront and sears the customers inside.

My favorite coffee shop in SF! Well lit, kind staff, great coffee and amazing bread. I spend a couple hours here journaling and working every Sunday. Sometimes it's hard to get a seat but it's worth the wait.

They don't have wifi or vanilla syrup. I get that you have to maintain the pretentious vibe but bitter coffee and $4 toast isn't going to do it for me. Having exposed wood and an open layout will probably be enough to keep tourists and unemployed people coming back, but if you're looking to actually do work in a coffee shop look elsewhere.

Fantastic place. The coffee is delicious and the place is chill. No plugs however do it's only good for get togethers or fully charged laptops with independent internet connection. However, compared to the divisadero street options, it's my choice. The desert is also delicious. The baristas are prpfessionals and very helpful if you have specific asks. There might be a line when you arrive but it's worth the wait.

Latte was delicious and served quickly. We found a nice table quickly and even at 9am! There was a perfect heart in the foam. 😍 There is also a lovely parklet out front which is nice even though it was a bit chilly.  I'll be returning!

Crowded but seats come easily enough. Incredibly tasty fresh bread though the toast menu, a rotating set of about 3 toppings and 4 breads. Well poured coffee but inconsistent timing could mean a cold late by the time the toast is ready. Pieces of toast have been shrinking in size lately, when it was already expensive.
Amazing Toats! A little too crown on Saturday

The mill is the best place to get coffee, bread, and get lost reading a good book. While the lines can get long and the setting can be loud, it's a wonderful place to stop by for an hour or so. There's no wifi but for good reason as I think people would really then hang around too much. Don't worry too much about which piece of toast to get as they all taste good :)

Best latte I ever had (so much better than starbucks no joke!) and the girl at the counter was so very friendly and tolerant of my questions to get one that was ok for my diabetic self :)  Update: even though I'm only in San Fran a few times a year,  went back with my boyfriend and his sister when she was in town and that latte was still just as good as I remembered.  It's so far the only latte I like without anything- no sweetener of any kind.  It's just so smooth and the milk is enough on its own here.  I wish they had a San Jose branch.

I still can't get over the fact that I'm paying $4 for toast but it is toast done well with very hearty bread and equally hearty spreads.  Lots of Instagramers hang out here and the light in the morning by the windows is great for making portraits.  If I go here it is for the ambience and to meet people.

What more can one say - top notch coffee, home made bread in the truest sense of the phrase, and an open and inviting atmosphere.  Is it expensive?  Yes.  Is it worth it?  Absolutely.  Make sure to arrive early to avoid the line out the door
Bread lives up to the hype.  Had square croissant with sesame inside cream cheese and chives.   Had sesame bread.  Hearty bread but a tad salty.
The garlic knot was ok, the hot chocolate was flavorless, the service was passive aggressive
Coffee is exceptional. Breads cooked on premise. Interior is beautiful. The line goes out the door, but it doesn't seem to matter. Blue bottle and Sightglass fans will love this place.

Lovely interior. Amazing iced coffee. People from all strokes of (middle class+) life. And very very good bread. The line is always a bit long but the employees got their routines on fleek and it always moves forward fast.

Didn't get a chance to try their baked goods, only had an espresso, which was a bit on the burnt side, perhaps too roasted  (a common issue in many coffee shops). However, I enjoyed the cool ambience and watching one of the baristas preparing perfectly crafted macchiatoes and lattes.

Great coffee (four barrel) and toast (cinnamon-sugar and Nutella). Super hip environment. Would be five stars if they did a better job tidying up after the swarms of sloppy yuppies that make a mess everywhere (tables and bathrooms). I feel bad deducting a star due to sloppy clientele, but it really does detract from the experience.

The artisanal toast trend is an odd one to comprehend, but The Mill's selections are quite good and don't break the bank.  Be sure to arrive early in the morning before the rush for a Zen like atmosphere. Afterwards, it gets pretty hectic.  Also, don't miss out on the nightly pizza. Delicious garlicy crust.

It was ok. My mocha wasn’t that good. My toast was better. $16 I would’ve at least expected WiFi. Went to avoid starbucks, grab a snack and get a little work done but- guess I’m heading to Starbucks anyway.

From the coffee to the toast, everything at The Mill is all about attention to detail. They're Doing It Right over here. It's not expensive, but it's not cheap; excellence rarely is.  If you're lucky enough to stop in while there's an einkorn loaf on the rack, grab it. It's one of the best breads I've ever had—and that's saying something because I've had the seed feast, too.
