Worth the price and the bougie scarlet letter. They serve the best damn toast, and you'd be hard-pressed to convince me otherwise. Nice open air, good bread, and lively. Hit this place up if you're in SF!

Great coffee and baked goods, love the vibe and is normally quiet enough to read.  No WiFi, which means fewer laptops (which I like).  If you plan to do work here, prep your phone for tethering the whole time.  Get the toast, cookies, or a latte and enjoy the breeze that they let fill the open layout.

Great Four-barrel coffee and delicious, house-made baked goods.  Calm, minimalist interior full of Divisadero hipsters.  Still, the place is friendlier than it first appears and there's no Wi-Fi, so only a few people are buried in their laptops. There's a nice parklet in front. Come in and have a pistachio croissant and take home a warm loaf of bread.

Monday night and you don't care for football, go to the Mill for pizza night. Just one veggie choice but it's always good. Put you order in, slices or whole pizza then find a place to sit. Since it takes 30 minutes walk on down to Bi-Rite for beer or wine and your set. If you know how good Josey Baker bread is just imagine the pizza. Busy and a bit loud but a fun and interesting night out. Grab a place to sit as it does get crowded and check with them for when the pizza is done since it's low key on the delivery aspect.

coffee tastes rushed and it's noisy in here.. that said, it's decent and they use good beans - maybe I'll try a drip coffee. they have fresh bread and it's a cool space. I'd come again but I would probably not go out of my way to do so.
“Great place for working on laptop”  No wifi, no power outlets. Gentrified and sterile, staff that look at you funny when you ask questions.
Very nice place for morning breakfast. Amazing atmosphere, service and taste.

With some of the nicest baristas in the city, The Mill is definitely one place a tourist (or a local) shouldn't pass up. Steps from Alamo Square, this Four Barrel/Josey Baker Bread collaboration features only coffee drinks, and homemade pastries and bread for the liking. Be sure to come in early to smell the loaves of bread baking in the oven...and don't underestimate the almond milk lattes...they are better than the cow's milk ones!

This place is definitely overrated. The bread is decent, but the prices you pay and for what you get is hysterical. Plenty of places with same quality avocado toast and almost half the price. The avocado proportion to bread is also laughable. I either need twice as much avocado or half the slice of bread.  What's even funnier is that a slice of bread and jam is $6 pre tax.

I purchased a bread from The Mill. The price tag was mismatched. It was a simple thing. I warned the cashier. Instead of fixing the issue, she was upset with me. I had a bad customer experience. Other than that, the Mill is in a nice location and the bread was delicious. When I pay, $7.50 for a bread, I expect at least above an average customer experiencing.

Just.the.bomb.  Bread Fresh bread Fresh delicious warm fantastic yummy bread Great coffees cold and hot PB like you've never had Many butters and jams Delish  PS Kayla recommended drinks and a slice today - GREAT! Almond butter and honey big shout out for the recs

Go to the Mill to work your eyes, your mind, and your mouth. Coffee is good to the last drip, and the one cashier looks like something out of the movie, " BlowUp " or a " This is England " Episode. The waffles are savory, and so are the other items. If you're looking for a seat past 9am, forget it. Go here early. This has a heavy rotating crowd, which is nice because there are less laptop campers!

I wanted to give three stars since their main food option is toast and it's not large pieces and yet quite pricey, but being a cafe that doesn't have WiFi (free or otherwise) just seems Draconian to me. The cashier seemed oh so unfazed at my incredulity about this and thought it no big deal. It really confounded me. Not a place I plan to revisit.

Bread larger than the toppings. No egg which you'd think would be a natural accompaniment for toast. Coffee OK but got asked for a 'size' for a flat white (hint: they're always 6oz). Sunday's NY Times (it's Thursday). SF's "fancy toast" is incredibly weak compared to NY, Melbourne or London.

The long lines here are an indication that this Hayes Valley coffee shop is special and has been discovered. The Mill serves artisanal coffee, espressos and fresh pastries. They have Affogato on the menu: a scoop of vanilla ice cream served in hot espresso.  Right behind the counter is an open kitchen space where the staff at The Mill prepares baked goods and the baristas froth up milk for lattes. It's not walled off from the customer's sitting area, which is furnished with warm wooden chairs and open community style tables. The high windows facing Divisadero let in sunlight.  When I visited with my friend, it was a Saturday and The Mill was packed. If you can get a seat, it's a comfortable environment, but it took about five to ten minutes for a seat to open up at peak hours. As you'd expect, it was noisy with chatter, so it might be better to look for a smaller place if your objective is to get work done. However, if you're looking for a nice place for a coffee date with a friend, this is the place.
My favorite bread & coffee shop.im SF.  Really good freshly baked bread

I'm apprehensive in saying it, but I think the pizza here is better than Arizmendi's. They also have beer, which is always a plus.  We tried their "Big Salad" too. It was very fresh, and I always appreciate a Seinfeld reference.
This was the best place I have ever been for breakfast. The bread is amazing. The atmosphere is really awesome. Their toasts are SO GOOD. The staff is all friendly and awesome.

Yes, the hype is true: get the toast, it *is* as good as they say.  Also, if you love their sourdough bread, ask them about their classes! They run workshops in the evening, and it's a great experience.

Friendly staff, the pizzas are thin and crunchy crust. Tried the garlic knots and someone in my party found them too spicy, too much chili flakes but they were tasty, more similar to a mini bread loaf than a knot though.
Great coffee and cookies but I can't believe that in 2022 the place doesn't offer Wi-fi to clients.
Classy coffee spot. 0 outlets.

Unfortunately, this place is usually crowded and it's hard to find a seat. Many people of camp out here. If you around a bit, someone's bound to finish their coffee and toast and head out. Alternatively, if it's a nice day, go to Alamo Square Park nearby and enjoy your beverage and baked good there.

I can't believe how much I paid for a slice of toast. It was a good slice of toast, real thick, but... it was a slice of toasted bread with butter and salt on it. Actually, the salt may have been special. Like salt from an ancient meteor strike in the Himalayas or something.  Your best bet is to buy a whole loaf of bread, which they make right there. It looks and smells absolutely fantastic. Then, unplug someone's laptop, plug in your smuggled toaster, and voila—you're in business!
Favorite coffee place in SF!
Aesthetics are spot-on. It's a beautiful place with great coffee drinks and croissants, but often very crowded and difficult to grab a seat. Outdoor seating could be more comfortable.

Here's what you'll find at The Mill. 1. Outstanding coffee and espressos (Four Barrel beans). 2. Made from scratch toast with fresh and creative toppings. 3. The world's most expensive toast. 4. A very crowded space.

Forget Italy, forget Seattle -- San Francisco may be the best coffee city in the world at the moment. It has the traditional Italian style coffees in North Beach, the dark roast of Peets, and the latest batch of new lighter complex roasts from Blue Bottle, Sightglass, Ritual, or what they serve here at The Mill, which is Four Barrel.  The coffee here is superb, and the interior is beautifully designed.  Be prepared for very long lines -- the only weekend afternoon I saw with no lines was when all the hipsters were away at Burning Man.
What can you say about shelling $5 for a toast? It's worth it. Bread was baked to perfection, and the cinnamon plus sugar was a real treat.  Good service, with a smile.

I never knew there were places that specialized in toast before. I also didn't know toast could ever be something I'd want to go back for, but now I do. I got the bird bread, but also got to try some of the rye and the sesame, and I think the rye was probably my favorite (served with cream cheese and black pepper on it). I also got a macchiato, which was as good as any other macchiato I've ever had. Obviously it's a specialty shop (toast and coffee, primarily) but there is definitely something to be said for sticking with what you know and what you can do amazingly well. It was pretty packed when I was there (mid-afternoon on a Saturday) and a little slow, so definitely not a place where you should expect to be in and out quickly.

I like coming here for a quick snack and beverage to catch up with friends. By snack I mean the infamous $3.50 toast and by beverage I mean coffee (usually an Americano, Drip, Cold Brew or a Macchiato.) The space is warm and inviting, but the music they play can get a bit loud for my taste. I like seeing Josie Baker's staff make bread as well. My preferred toast is the one with pumpkin butter on wheat sprinkled with sea salt.
Not usually a coffee drinker so I ordered a mocha. And it was the best mocha I've ever had -- deep rich chocolate flavors, kinda like hot coco I'd get from Dandelion chocolate.
Always a great expressed coffee , made with some of the best beans in town. And warm Josey Baker bread! Nice people, very cool environment with vinyl playing the background.
It's not cheap for what is essentially just a posh slice of toast, but it's delicious, and the setting is beautiful. Great Four Barrel coffee, and awesome chocolate chip scones!
Overpriced trendy hipster spot that only sells toast one slice at a time for $8 each with some weak, thin, avocado slop on the top. And $3.75 for a small coffee is a rip off too.

Toast is of course what you come for here. And yes, it is quite delicious. I would give this 5 stars for the toast and their great coffee, but part of me cries inside with every bite of that delicious $8 toast...

I eat pizza 4 out of 7 days, just a slice. Did I say I like pizza? I find it to be the perfect snack - carbs, proteins, vitamins.  So whenever Arizmendi in the Mission has a day off (Tuesdays) or they have unnatural toppings (I am looking at you comice pears or potato or something ungodly that you simply do not put on pizza without giving an Italiano grandmother a mini heart attack), I head over to The Mill.  This is a hipster place that plays hipster music and is frequented by hipsters who like hipster beer and hipster food at hipster prices. To be fair, the food, craft beer, coffee and bread (Josey Baker bread) are great.  Every evening from 6-9 (except first Monday of every month) they serve you pizza by the slice. One seasonal veggie and another classic cheese slice. It's a pretty big slice for $3.50 (plus taxes) and you can tell it has high quality ingredients.  The magic is in the dough, which is baked perfectly, light, airy, crisp and salty (think tiny chunks of salt that hit your palette as you bite the crust).  I usually get it to go, and I reheat it at 450 until the cheese starts to boil a wee bit. And voila, it's ready to be gone in 60 seconds.  If you are craving a slice, without breaking the bank or your daily calorie budget, this is the place to be in the evening. You can usually find a spot on weekday evenings, and get your slice within 3 minutes.  The toppings can be from onion and mushroom to 4 cheese (quattro formaggi) to something ungodly such as pineapple and jalapeño (sounds better than it tastes).  Try this pizza for the dough. Also it's not gooey or overflowing with oil. So you won't feel tres guilty. If you want to balance it out, they also have a salad (7 bucks I think) that can make you justify that delicious slice.

The Mill is everything I dream of in a coffee shop — atmosphere, warmth, good coffee, great food and pastry options. I wish COVID  was over so I could sit inside and write /people watch. Can’t wait to go back!
The toast was fantastic and the coffee was deliciously above average! I will definitely go again!
Nice place, lots of space. Very hipster. Coffee was good but not great, same goes for the employees taking your order. Therefore I feel the prices are a too high. Also no wifi..
As brilliant as expected - second home in SF
Great ambiance. But everything is way over priced. I bought a loaf of multigrain bread there once and it was not cooked through. It seems like expired yeast was used or something. Huge waste of $7.

$4 toast, you say? Isn't that a little ridiculous? Yes, yes it is. Ridiculous and delicious. I'm apparently a sucker for fancy toast and Four Barrel coffee.  Although, if you're looking for a cafe to hang out and get some work done or have a little chat, this isn't the one. Seating is limited and it's constantly busy.

I wasn't honestly as impressed as I would have liked to be. The nutella toast was "meh" and I LOVE nutella. I felt the same about the apricot spread. Moreover, my pour over coffee was disappointing, which for me was the saddest part. I bought 2 loaves of bread to go which I really liked and why I gave it 4 stars. Maybe I just went on an off day, but maybe there's too much hype.
Fantastic cortado. Great atmosphere. Actually has some decent seating if you need to get a little work done.
Their toasts and espresso drinks are really good. It's pricey but worth it if you appreciate a good cup of coffee. It's also overly trendy, for better and for worse.
I love the look, layout and feel.  You walk in and immediately I wish I worked there.  The smell of the coffee is  intoxicating and beyond delightful.  The toast are Jam packed with flavor.
Love, love, love.  Great food. Fantastic bread. Wonderful concept. Great coffee. And there is always a collection of trendy, we'll dressed, good looking people at this joint!

The Mill isn't just doing things right- they are setting the standard.  Josey Baker Bread is the fundamental element to The Mill's daily offerings of toast. Toppings range from cream cheese and black pepper, to honey, maple syrup, or house-made nutella.  Their Four Barrel coffee pairs perfectly. Watch carefully as your barista crafts your drink, because no where else do they have the same care and passion for creating a delicious cup of coffee.  Okay, now I'm hungry and want a mocha and a couple slices of toast.
Good atmosphere, but not a place for Italian espresso. The espresso is too concentrated (too much coffee grind?) and you can't have a regular one, only a double.
All about the cinnamon sugar toast. Great place for coffee, to read, chill. Nice and open space so you can enjoy your coffee without feeling cramped.

Food items: Tea, coffee, coffee beans, toast, jam, almond butter, pastries, and juices always; and pizza after 6pm  Non food items: Pottery, plants, kitchen linens, coffee accessories, tea accessories, kitchen accessories  Seating inside and outside. Hard to find a seat, place is often packed.  Local art decorating the walls  No wifi  ~$5 for a latte ~$7 for toast
How could toast be so good? It's better than toast should be. It's $4, sure, but it's somehow worth every penny. The coffee from Four Barrel is on point too.
Great bread and lattes! All bread baked in house, which really shows through, and the quality of their coffee is excellent.

Hipster bakery: Yes, there's a record player and vinyl LPs on the shelf to admire as you wait for your thick slab of toast.  We sampled a variety of their special toast concoctions and my favorite included cracked pepper with cream cheese and butter with housemade jam. Yes, you're paying $4 but it's just as much as a pastry and a big portion--its certainly not a slice of dinky Wonder bread. It's artisanal with quality grain.
I'm not a coffee drinker, but come here for their fresh bread which is amazingly yummy! I recommend going off hours since it can get busy on the weekends.
The toast is actually pretty good, if pricey. Not a fan enough to want to stand in the long line during crowded brunchy times. Crowd is trendy/ techy/ banal, may annoy longtime San Franciscans.

The Mill will show you, when it comes to making toast, you're doing it wrong.  Yes, the toast is expensive. Yes, the artisinal staff have the beards, tattoos, and suspenders you'd expect to find at an artisinal coffee & toast shop. But also, yes, the toast is delicious. Worth a visit.
Great coffee, good sandwiches, amazing embience.

This bakery/coffee shop on Divisidero in SF serves up my new favorite coffee, Fourbarrel.  That in itself is enough to make me stop by but then there is their fresh bread.  From which AMAZING and thick slices are toasted and topped to order!  All of that and the fact that they are spinning vinyl records on an old school turntable!  Beach Boys!  Never thought you'd see a place famous for their toast?  This is it!
Famous when they first opened for $4 Toast. People waited in lines for it. Delicious, and now quintessential SF, so perhaps worth trying once. Best coffee in the area.

My friend took me here for the first time today. Things started out well with me literally parking outside. Inside the staff was great. Me being a seattlite, the coffee here was fantastic.  I had a  cappuccino.
Edit: they seem to "run out of toast" really early now. If you want toast, don't bother coming in the afternoon.  Great coffee, great baked goods, great space and atmosphere.

NO wifi, NO toilet, Expensive => NO 2nd time.  Thanks to all the pretentious reviews here, I had the WORST coffee experience in the whole America let alone SF. Should NOT support this kind of business, exploiting the vibe of the neighborhood to prey on consumers!

We were visiting San Francisco with friends, and of course had to have infamous "fancy toast"...The Mill fit the bill! Toast, check. Coffee from cute pottery, check. Perfect pristine atmosphere, check.
5 stars down to 4 for increasing prices to $14 for toast and coffee. Minus another one for being a coffee shop without wifi. The coffee is good tho and the toast used to be.
Amazing coffee, great atmosphere & service! Would definitely go back only next visit!
Coffee is locked in and the bakery is a lovely treat to your nose, NO wifi. Vinyl music and the constant order calls keeps a nice vibe.
The space is beautiful – I want to come back just to see it again! Coffee was solid and the avocado toast was hearty too.
They have some pretty tasty breads and toast options. Decent cappuccino and pleasant staff. It gets a little too noisy for me sometimes tho.
My favorite coffee shop in San Francisco. Love the adventure bread. Service is nice, coffee is great.
Energy has been weird the last few times I’ve been in. No neighborhood feeling or saying hello. Feels kind of intense and transactional.
Black coffee... Tasted great. Staff was super friendly and there is quite a bit of seating. Huge open room and a cool location (Nopa) good for a morning coffee and a walk around.

It is a gourmet cafe near Alamo Square. As a coffee lover, this was the most delicious cafe latte I had during my trip to San Fran. This is a shop that deserves a higher rating. The milk is very soft, and the coffee is moderately nutty and has a deep flavor. Recommended for takeout when going to Alamo Square

Bakery and cafe located in San Francisco, California, USA. As the name suggests, they make their own bread from the flour itself and bake and sell it.  It seems that baking work is still going on in the back loft in a large and wide open space. There are several food menus using bread. Ordered avocado toast and cinnamon sugar. It's avocado toast, which is a common menu in California, but the kick is to sprinkle Maldon salt on top. It is also sprinkled with cinnamon sugar, which enhances the umami taste. The bread underneath is called country bread, similar to rye bread.  For coffee, I use Dongne's Four Barrel Coffee. It has a rich coffee aroma, probably because it has just been roasted, and the latte taste is better due to the slight acidity. The atmosphere itself is just California.

A popular cafe opened by the popular San Francisco coffee chain FOURBARREL COFFEE with Josey Baker Bread. The coffee is of course delicious, but the selling point here is the bread baked in the back of the store. It is standard to order toast and coffee with various original tastes such as DARK MOUNTAIN RYE (cream cheese + black pepper + sea salt) using that bread. The clerk was also very friendly.
The bakery cafe near Alamo Square is famous, so there are many visitors, and simple brunch like toast is good.
